_exec_summary.SummaryText:
IWI NEWPORT NEWS

Refrigeration System Process Description

Overview

This system is a single stage configuration utilizing computerized control for system operation.  There are a total of four screw compressors that handle the refrigeration loads. Three of the four compressors operate on a -25°F recirculator package or the ultra low recirculator package that operates at 
-30°. The compressors have side ports to maintain a +20°F high side trap.  

There are three separate suction temperatures a -25°F low temp. recirculator to maintain freezer a -35° recirculator to maintain blast rooms and a +20°F high side trap. The high side trap maintains dock temperatures and sub cools liquid to the low side.

There is two rooftop mounted evaporative condensers with remote sumps.  There is also two, glycol shell and tube units use for under floor heating.  A Hansen auto-purger is also used to remove non-condensable materials.  A system dump is also incorporated should a need to purge the system arise. 

 
Process Description

Liquid Side

The liquid supply for the system starts at the Condensers.  The Condensers change superheated vapor discharged from the Compressors and remove a sufficient amount of heat such that the vapor changes to a liquid (condenses).  This condensed liquid leaves Condenser units EC-1 via a 3¿ inch pipe and flows to the thermosyphon header and the Thermosyphon Receiver (V-1).  

The  thermosyphon receiver supplies liquid to each screw compressor for cooling of the oil.  These oil coolers are mounted on the side of each screw compressor unit.  The refrigerant in the oil coolers naturally recirculates to and from the Thermosyphon Receiver when there is a heat load.

The high-pressure liquid also leaves the thermosyphon receiver via a 3 line and feeds the Hansen auto-purger unit and High Temperature trap (V-2).  The High Temperature trap is operated at +20°F.  The liquid supply to V-2 is controlled by a Hanson level control and solenoid.

   

The Low Tempe

rature Recirculator is operated at -25°F.  A Hanson level control and solenoid device controls the liquid supply to V-3.  The liquid from the Low Temperature Recirculator is pumped to the -15° F freezer air units and the ultra low recirculator.


 
Vapor Side

The Compressors remove the vapors from both the High Temperature Recirculator, Low Temperature Recirculator and the Ultra Low Temperature Recirculator vessels.  

  Screw compressors: C-1 through C-4 remove the vapors from the High Temperature trap through side ports.  Screw Compressor C-2 through C-4 removes vapors from the Low and Ultra Low Temperature Recirculators.    

The discharge of all the compressors, C-1 through C-4, is sent to the main discharge header, which feeds the Condenser units.  The Condensers change superheated vapor discharged from the Compressors and remove a sufficient amount of heat such that the vapor changes to a liquid (condenses).  

Some of the superheated discharge vapors (hot gas) are sent to the one floor heater.  These floor  heater condense the vapors and utilize this removed heat for increasing the temperature of the glycol.  This warmed glycol is then utilized for keeping the freezer sub-floor temperature above freezing.
 
Additionally, as required, some of the superheated discharge vapors (hot gas) are diverted for use as a defrosting medium.  This defrost gas is sent to the Air Units   for removal of ice that has built up on the coils.


 
Definitions

Thermosyphon System

A thermosyphon system is a means by which an uninterrupted supply of liquid refrigerant can be supplied to the compressor units.  This liquid utilizes a shell and tube or plate heat exchanger to keep the compressor's oil cooled and thus allowing the units to operate at the Manufacturer's recommended temperature.  

Liquid ammonia is supplied to the inlet of the heat exchanger.  When a heat load is applied to the heat exchanger, some of the liquid is vaporized.  This vapor-liquid mixture that is less den

se than a pure liquid.  The denser liquid (supply) displaces the lighter vapor-liquid mixture thus pushing the mixture out of the heat exchanger and back to the Thermosyphon Receiver.  This difference in density creates a natural circulation.


Single Stage Compression System

A single stage compressor system utilizes one or more compressors to pump the refrigerant vapor from the low-pressure side to the high-pressure side of the refrigeration system.  Each compressor discharges directly to the condenser units via a common header. 


Recirculator System

A recirculator system is a combination of a vessel, pumps, valves and other components used to feed a refrigeration circuit.  The pumps supply liquid to the various evaporators.  The outlet of the evaporators (consisting of liquid and vapor) is returned to the recirculator vessel for separation of the liquid and vapor.

The application can be either a low temp or high temp application. The liquid feed can be sub-cooled through an intercooler or fed directly from the receiver.
